section.title: Shell Account
section.para: Important Note: this feature can be deactivated by your CodeX site administrator and may therefore be unavailable in your organization.
If the CodeX administrators have enabled this feature, each registered user receives its own Unix shell account on the CodeX Shell Account server. You can access your CodeX Shell Account in 2 ways:

listitem.para: SSH: the secured remote shell is the preferred way to connect to the CodeX Shell Account server. SSH clients are available for all platforms (Windows, Linux, Unix and Mac) and allows a secure link with your personal directories. It also provides you with a number of other useful utilities like scp for remote file transfer. Use the Unix "cd" command to change the current working directory. section.title: FTP Anonymous Storage Space
section.para: Each project receives its own FTP storage, the Anonymous FTP Space. If you need a controlled access to your files, it is recommended to use the web-based File Release System ().

The anonymous FTP space can be used by the project members to upload any kind of documents or project data and deliverables they want. This storage will then be visible to any CodeX users and all files placed in this directory can be freely downloaded. So make sure that you use this storage space for world readable files only.

listitem.para: Anonymous Users access: use an ftp client to connect to &SYS_DOWNLOAD_HOST;. Use "ftp" as login and your email address as the password. Then cd /pub/projectname to access the FTP Anonymous space.

Project Members access: use an ftp client to connect to &SYS_DOWNLOAD_HOST;. Use CodeX login and password and then type cd /var/lib/codex/ftp/pub/projectname to access the FTP Anonymous space. From there project members have both read and write access which means that they can upload files.

section.title: SOAP API
section.para:
CodeX provides a SOAP API to access CodeX through web-services. At this time, only session (login/logout) and tracker services are available.
Note: the mail notification is not active with the SOAP API
A human-friendly description of the services is available at http://&SYS_DEFAULT_DOMAIN;/soap/. It is a list of services, with a description of each function, its input, ouput and documentation
A more detailed description of the services is also available with the more formal WSDL language at http://&SYS_DEFAULT_DOMAIN;/soap/?wsdl. The WSDL also includes the types definition.

section.title: CodeX Command Line Interface (CLI)
section.para: Another way to use CodeX is to use the command line interface (CLI). It's a client application that use the SOAP API to interact with the CodeX server. At this time, only session (login/logout) and tracker services are available. The CLI is currently missing a few features of the SOAP API (e.g. it is not possible to attach a file, a CC address or a dependency to an artifact), and the mail notification is not active with the CLI.
The full CLI documentation is available at http://&SYS_DEFAULT_DOMAIN;/documentation/cli/pdf/en_US/CodeX_CLI.pdf
